title: Primordial Chaos, No. 16
didYouKnow: In her will, af Klint instructed that her work be kept secret for [20 years](https://www.moma.org/interactives/moma_through_time/1980/af-klint/) after her death, because she felt audiences of the time were not ready to appreciate or understand it.

title: Woman with a Sunflower
didYouKnow: The sunflower was a symbol of the [Suffrage movement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_in_the_women%27s_suffrage_movement_in_the_United_States), and Cassatt sold this painting, among many others, to raise money for the cause.

title: Open Window, Collioure
didYouKnow: Matisse was a leader of the [Fauvist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fauvism) movement, which featured bold, unnaturalistic color and unapologetic brushstrokes. "Les fauves" translates to "the wild beasts" in French.

title: The Arch
didYouKnow: Tanner moved from [Pennsylvania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania) to [Paris](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paris) in 1891, hoping to avoid the racism he faced as an [African-American artist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_African-American_visual_artists). His work was hugely successful in France, and he was knighted to the [Legion of Honor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legion_of_Honor). Tanner lived in Paris for the rest of his life, but supported civil rights organizations like the [NAACP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NAACP) from abroad.

title: The Seine
didYouKnow: This work was a small, [plein air](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/En_plein_air) [oil sketch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oil_sketch). Tanner's landscapes often feature dreamy, pastel hues.

title: The Two Fridas
didYouKnow: This double self-portrait was painted the year Kahlo and painter [Diego Rivera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diego_Rivera) divorced. The Frida on the right holds a tiny portrait of Rivera, that's fed by one of her veins.

title: Garden View, Brooklyn
didYouKnow: Bridges was a [pioneer](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/12/arts/fidelia-bridges-overlooked.html) in both watercolor painting and animal rights activism. She combined these passions by illustrating books about birds.

title: Autumn Colors on the Qiao and Hua Mountains (「鵲華秋色圖」卷)
didYouKnow: The calligraphy at the top tell us that Zhao Mengfu made this painting as a [gift](https://smarthistory.org/zhao-mengfu-autumn-colors-mountains/)for his close friend Zhou Mi.

title: Ace of Clubs and Four of Diamonds
didYouKnow: Gris was a key figure in [Cubism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubism), alongside [Picasso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Picasso) and [Braque](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Braque). Gris also designed ballet sets and costumes for the [Ballets Russes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballets_Russes).

title: The Artist's Garden at Eragny
didYouKnow: There were [eight](https://www.britannica.com/art/the-eight-Impressionist-exhibitions) [Impressionist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impressionism) exhibitions in Paris from 1874 to 1886. Pissarro was the [only artist](https://www.christies.com/en/stories/collecting-guide-camille-pissarro-02cf6e53a4cd4a369aec02a79831a6bf) to show work in all eight. He was a mentor to artists like [Gauguin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Gauguin) and [Cézanne](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne).

title: Political Drama
didYouKnow: Robert Delaunay and his wife [Sonia Delaunay](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonia_Delaunay) were leaders of the [Orphism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphism_%28art%29) movement, a colorful response to the neutral tones of [Cubism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubism). Orphism is also the name of an ancient Greek [religion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orphism). Both are named after the mythical poet [Orpheus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orpheus).

title: Evocation of Roussel
didYouKnow: Redon's dreamlike, fantastical art was a precursor to [Surrealism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism) and [Dadaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dada).

title: Flecks of Foam
didYouKnow: Later in his career, Dearth began painting with thickly applied, vibrant jets of paint. This helped capture the movement of what became a frequent subject for him: [tide pools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tide_pool) in [Brittany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brittany).

title: Peaches on a Plate
didYouKnow: Pierre-Auguste Renoir is the father of filmmaker [Jean Renoir](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Renoir), who some consider one of the [greatest directors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jean_Renoir#Legacy) of all time.

title: Night Scene in the Yoshiwara
didYouKnow: Ōi often collaborated with her father, [Hokusai](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hokusai), the [ukiyo-e](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukiyo-e) printmaker known for [The Great Wave off Kanagawa](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Great_Wave_off_Kanagawa). Oi's use of light and shadows, here hiding identites outside of a brothel, was unusal for [Edo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edo_period) artwork.

title: Polypodium Phegopteris (Northern beech fern)
didYouKnow: Atkins, an English botanist and photographer, made [cyanotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanotype) to illustrate her book, [Photographs of British Algae: Cyanotype Impressions](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/286656), which is considered the first ever photo book.

title: Mount Taibai, 太白山圖
didYouKnow: Meng is one of the [Four Masters of the Yuan Dynasty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Masters_of_the_Yuan_Dynasty), a group that promoted [literati painting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_School), which combined [painting with poetry and calligraphy](https://www.berkshirepublishing.com/ecph-china/2018/01/08/literati-painting/).

title: Young Woman Combing Her Hair
didYouKnow: Although Blanchard is mainly known for her contributions to [Cubism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubism), this [Expressionist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expressionism) oil painting was part of her post-Cubist look at the [human condition](https://www.museopicassomalaga.org/en/prensa/maria-blanchard-a-painter-in-spite-of-cubism) through portraits.
